newsitem.title: USA: GAINSCO SEES BOTTOM LINE IMPROVING IN H2.
newsitem.headline: GAINSCO SEES BOTTOM LINE IMPROVING IN H2.

text.p: Gainsco Inc, reporting declining revenues and profits for the first half, said Wednesday it expected better performance for the rest of the year.

"We feel comfortable with an improving bottomline for the second half," said chief executive Joseph Macchia in an interview. He added the insurer expected to write between $115 million to $125 million in gross premiums and post at least an 18 percent return on equity for the full year.
With shareholders equity of $109.4 million on December 31, the insurer said it expects an after-tax $19.7 million profit for the full year.

Gainsco Wednesday reported a $4.4 million net on gross premiums of $26.9 million in the second quarter ended June 30, compared with a $4.5 million net on $29.2 million in gross premiums in the same period of 1996.
For the first half, Gainco earned $7.6 million and wrote $50.0 million in gross premiums, compared with an $8.8 million net and $53.8 milion in gross premiums in the first half of 1996.
Macchia said the company returned an annualized 13.9 percent on shareholders' equity in the first half.

The chief executive projected better results in the second half because the insurer "tightened up its underwriting," scrapping taxi insurance programs in New Jersey and Connecticut and a coal truck insurance program in Kentucky.
Macchia added he expected a new dealer-oriented car insurance program in Texas to contribute to earnings in the second half.
The insurer's stock traded at 9-3/16 Wednesday morning, up 1/8. Wednesday, 6 August 1997 14:00:49 ENDS nN06222882
